Graphical abstract The effect of activation gas on the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) performance of copper and potassium promoted precipitated iron-based catalysts was investigated in an earlier study [Catal. Lett. 144 (2014) 1624-1635]. In that study, CO and syngas (H2/CO=0.7) activation methods were tested after varying the copper promoter loading (0, 2, and 5%, atomic ratios relative to iron). At similar CO conversion level, the selectivities for the CO-activated catalysts were identical for the various copper loaded catalysts, whereas for the syngas activated catalysts, light hydrocarbon (methane and C2–C4) selectivities decreased and higher hydrocarbon (C5+) selectivities increased with increasing copper loading. To understand the reason for that behavior, the catalyst samples were characterized by XANES/EXAFS spectroscopy following each activation procedure before and after exposure to FTS conditions. Cu K-edge normalized XANES results indicate that for the syngas activated catalyst copper is present primarily in the Cu1+ state, whereas for CO activated catalyst the copper is more reduced (greater fraction in the Cu0 state). The Cu1+ in the syngas activated catalyst behaved like K1+; therefore, the C5+ selectivity was enhanced and light hydrocarbon selectivity was suppressed. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Iron-based catalyst Activation gas Cu oxidation state Product selectivity XANES/EXAFS 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is considered to be one of the most attractive routes to convert syngas (H2 +CO) derived from coal, natural gas, and biomass into liquid fuels and chemicals. Several group VIII metals such as iron, cobalt, and ruthenium are known to be active catalysts for FTS. There are some benefits to using iron-based catalysts. When FTS is performed with hydrogen-deficient syngas (H2/CO≤1.0) as derived from coal or biomass, the intrinsic water–gas shift (WGS) activity is important for increasing the H2/CO ratio. Moreover, Fe catalysts can be prepared with high activity, and iron is lower in cost than either Co or Ru [1–4]. As-prepared FTS catalysts are composed of metal oxides that are inactive for FTS. Consequently, the as-prepared FTS catalysts must be subjected to an appropriate pre-treatment to chemically change them into an active form for FTS. Pretreatment of iron catalysts can have important influences on the FTS activity and selectivity. Potassium and copper are the chemical promoters most often used for industrial iron-based FTS catalysts. Extensive studies have been conducted to discover the functions of promoters in the FTS reaction [5–11]. It is widely accepted that potassium suppresses methane formation and increases the formation rate of heavier hydrocarbons through enhanced CO dissociation on iron based catalysts [5–12]. However, although consistent conclusions about the role of potassium in iron-based catalysts were obtained in many studies, fewer studies have dealt with the effect of Cu on such catalysts [9]. It is well known that copper can facilitate reduction of Fe oxides at low temperature and promote the formation of the active phase [13–20]. Cu is thus often used to improve catalyst performance and offset disadvantages of structural promoters (e.g., Fe-based catalysts). Although the function of copper in facilitating catalyst reduction has been widely accepted, its influence on the FTS product distribution has not been well addressed. The product selectivity is mainly dependent on the activation and reaction conditions. Some researchers have reported that the product selectivity either increases [5,9,16,18,20,21] or is suppressed [8,14,22] with Cu addition, while others have found that copper promotion has no effect [17,20,23,24] for various activation conditions. This was established by conducting the FTS reaction in both differential fixed-bed [5,8,14,17,22–24] and slurry-phase [9,16,18,20,21] reactors. Apart from detailed studies on the effects of the Cu promoter on catalyst reduction and FTS properties, the exact role and physicochemical state of the Cu species in promoted catalysts have rarely been studied directly. Wielers et al. [23,25] investigated hydrogen activated silica supported bimetallic Fe–Cu catalysts using Mössbauer and IR spectroscopies. The group reported that the Cu phase facilitated the reduction of Fe3+ species to Fe2+ (iron (II) silicate) species and, subsequently to zero-valent Fe. The zero-valent Fe was present as monometallic Fe particles as well as bimetallic Fe–Cu species. In an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study, Wachs et al. [17] characterized the surface of a pre-reduced, passivated FTS catalyst after in situ re-activation in H2 at 350°C and 16h FTS. The group observed agglomeration of the Cu phase on the surface of the reduced catalysts (i.e., decreasing Cu/Fe ratios). However, apart from the facilitation of the reduction of the passivated catalyst, no significant differences were found in FTS performance and carburization rate of the catalyst compared to an unpromoted Fe catalyst. Zhang et al. [18] used IR spectroscopy to probe the surface basicity of their Fe–Mn–Cu/SiO2 catalyst, but observed no significant differences between Cu-promoted and unpromoted catalysts. de Smit et al. [26] investigated the structural properties of unsupported (Fe2O3 and Fe2O3-Cu) and supported (Fe2O3-Cu-K-Si) catalysts during pretreatment (H2 and syngas) and FTS at 1bar by using combined X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) and wide angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) techniques. They reported that Cu significantly increased the reduction rate of the catalysts to zero-valent Fe species and increased the FTS activity and selectivity toward longer hydrocarbon products. After FTS, H2 pretreated catalysts mainly consisted of amorphous θ-Fe3C clusters (unsupported catalysts) or amorphous iron (II) silicate (supported catalyst), while the syngas pretreated catalysts all consisted mainly of γ-Fe and χ-Fe5C2. In another study by the same group [27], a combination of in situ XPS and XAS was used to study the influence of Cu as a promoter on the redox and surface properties of Fe-based FTS catalysts at 0.4 mbar. Cu species behaved quite differently in the case of supported and unsupported catalysts. CuO was reduced to Cu0 at temperatures as low as 200°C in the unsupported catalyst, while in the supported catalyst this reduction was delayed by the stabilization of Cu2O species by interaction with the SiO2 support. These two studies were carried out at low pressure (≤1bar) and very low CO conversions (∼1%) to limit the water partial pressure; however, industrial FTS is performed at ∼20bar pressure and high (∼50%) conversion. In our earlier study [20], the effect of activation gas over FTS for the performance of copper and potassium promoted precipitated iron-based catalysts was investigated. In that study, CO and syngas (H2/CO=0.7) activations were tested after varying the copper promoter loading. At similar CO conversion level, the selectivities for the CO-activated catalysts were very similar for the various copper loaded catalysts, whereas for the syngas activated catalysts, light hydrocarbon (methane and C2-C4) selectivities decreased and higher hydrocarbon (C5+) selectivities increased with increasing copper loading. The aim of the present study is to investigate why the copper-promoted iron catalysts exhibited higher C5+ selectivities for the syngas activation than with CO-activation. To investigate the role of promoter oxidation state on the chemical promoting effect of Cu, the catalysts were subjected to the CO or syngas activation treatments and withdrawn from the reactor prior to and following exposure to FTS reaction, and the samples were investigated using EXAFS and XANES spectroscopic techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Precipitated iron catalysts were prepared using a ferric nitrate solution obtained by dissolving iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (1.17M) in deionized water, and then tetraethylorthosilicate was added to provide the desired Fe:Si ratio. The mixture was stirred vigorously until the tetraethylorthosilicate had hydrolyzed. A flow of the tetraethylorthosilicate and iron nitrate mixture was added to a continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR) precipitation vessel together with a stream of ammonium hydroxide (15.6M) that was added at a rate to maintain a pH of 9.0. By maintaining the slurry pH at 9.0 and an average residence time of 6min, a base catalyst material containing iron and silicon was obtained. The slurry from the CSTR was filtered with a vacuum drum filter and the solids were washed twice with deionized water. The final filter cake was dried for 24h in an oven at 110°C with flowing air. For this study, the Fe:Si catalyst base powder was then impregnated with appropriate amounts of aqueous solutions of potassium nitrate and copper nitrate to produce the desired composition of atomic ratios related to iron of 100Fe:5.1Si:1.25K:5Cu. The catalyst precursor was first dried at 110°C overnight followed by impregnation, drying, and calcination at 350°C in an air flow for 4h. 2.2 Catalyst testing FTS experiments were conducted using a 1 L CSTR equipped with a magnetically driven stirrer with turbine impeller, a gas-inlet line, and a vapor outlet line with a SS fritted filter (2 microns) placed external to the reactor. A tube fitted with a stainless steel fritted filter (0.5 micron opening) extended below the liquid level of the reactor for withdrawing reactor wax and to maintain a nearly constant liquid level in the reactor. Separate mass flow controllers were used to control the flow of hydrogen and carbon monoxide at the desired rate. The gases were premixed in a mixing vessel prior to entering the reactor. Carbon monoxide was passed through a vessel containing lead oxide-alumina to remove traces of iron carbonyls. The mixed gases entered the CSTR below the stirrer, which was operated at 750rpm. The reactor slurry temperature was maintained constant (±1°C) by means of a temperature controller. Catalyst (∼10g) was added to Polywax-3000 (310g) in the CSTR, and then the reactor temperature was raised to 270°C at a rate of 1°C/min. The catalyst was activated using either CO or syngas (H2/CO=0.7) at a space velocity of 3.0sl/h/gcatalyst at 270°C and 175psig for 24h. FTS was then started by adding synthesis gas mixture to the reactor at a space velocity of 5.5sl/h/gFe and a H2/CO ratio of 0.7. The conversions of CO and H2 were obtained by gas chromatographic analysis (micro-GC equipped with thermal conductivity detectors) of the product gas mixture that passed through a trap held at 0°C. The reaction products were collected in three traps maintained at different temperatures: a hot trap (200°C), a warm trap (100°C), and a cold trap (0°C). The products were separated into different fractions (wax, oil, and an aqueous phase) for quantification. For example, the oil product from the warm and cold traps was combined after separation from the aqueous phase and prior to GC analysis. Hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and syngas conversion were obtained by using the following formula (where, N =moles of gas): Conversion ( % ) = N i n − N o u t N i n × 100 Reaction products were analyzed using several chromatographic procedures. The tail gas from the cold trap was analyzed with an online HP Quad series Micro GC and molar compositions of C1–C7 olefins and paraffins as well as H2, CO and CO2 were obtained. The analysis of the aqueous phase was performed using a HP 5790 GC with a thermal conductivity detector. The oil and light wax samples were mixed before being analyzed with an HP 5890 GC with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a 50m DB-5 column. The reactor wax analyses were carried out using a HP 5890 high temperature GC with an FID and a 30m alumina-clad HT-S column. 2.3 EXAFS/XANES spectroscopy The electronic structure and local atomic structure of the Cu promoter and extent of carburization in the iron catalyst following two activation procedures were investigated by XAS near the Cu K-edge (fluorescence mode) and Fe K-edge (transmission mode) at the Soft X-ray Micro characterization Beamline (SXRMB) at the Canadian Light Source, Inc. Catalyst samples were extracted from the continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR) under realistic FTS conditions in the in situ state and sealed in the wax (start-up solvent or product) for analysis. The samples were not exposed to air. The spectra (in energy space) were background subtracted and normalized with a Victoreen function and further normalized using a two-polynomial method with degree 1 for both the pre- and post-edge regions. Changes in the phase composition of the catalyst samples were analyzed by comparing the XANES region of the spectra using WinXAS [28]. EXAFS spectra were also treated using the WinXAS software. After background removal and normalization (previously described), the spectra were converted to k-space and background subtracted in k-space using a cubic spline fit. The Cu K-edge spectra were then truncated within the range of 2.5–7.5Å−1. Note that, due to the low Cu content, the useable range was shorter in comparison to the Fe edge data. Nevertheless, some useful information could be extracted with the more limited range. The iron K-edge spectra were truncated over the wider range of 2.5–11Å−1. To obtain the radial distribution function, the Fourier transform was carried out on the spectra in k-space making use of a Bessel window; a k-weighting of 1 was employed, to emphasize scattering by the light atoms. For Cu K-edge data, the first coordination shells were fitted in the k- and r-ranges of 2.5-7.5Å−1 and 1.0–3.0Å, respectively, while for Fe K-edge data, the ranges were 3.0–10.5Å−1 and 1.0–3.5Å, respectively. For Cu K-edge data, the experimental EXAFS data (k 1·χ(k)) were fitted with theoretically generated spectra derived from structural models including Cu-O (assuming a contribution not unlike that of Cu2O) and Cu-Cu in the metal. Cu2O has a cubic structure, with the Cu atoms arranged in an FCC sublattice, and the O atoms arranged in a BCC sublattice–the space group being P n3m. Cu metal has a standard FCC structure. Because floating the Debye-Waller factor led to physically unmeaningful fits, the Debye-Waller factor was derived from a Cu foil standard and fixed at 0.00538Å2. Structural fitting parameters used in the model included: global lattice expansion coefficients, for Cu-O (e.g., in Cu2O) and Cu-Cu in the metal; two global Δe 0 (one for copper oxide and one for copper metal)–the overall energy shift applied to each path; and coordination numbers for Cu-O (e.g., in Cu2O) and Cu-Cu. In order to constrain the fits to achieve more physically meaningful results, the data sets were fitted simultaneously. Fe K-edge experimental data (k 1·χ(k)) were fitted with theoretically generated spectra derived from structural models (Fig. 1), assuming the presence of χ-Fe2.5C (Hägg carbide) and Fe3O4 (magnetite). Hägg carbide has a monoclinic Bravais lattice with a C 2/c space group. The lattice parameters are a =11.504Å, b =4.524Å, c =5.012Å, and β =97.60°. Magnetite is isometric hexoctahedral in structure with a =8.391Å and a space group of F d3m. With the use of the ATOMS software [29], structural information of each of the phases (including information in Table 1 ) was transformed into spatial coordinates, which were then employed by the FEFF software [30] to calculate the scattering paths (Tables 2 and 3 ). The scattering paths specified in Tables 2 and 3 were thus used as inputs for the FEFFIT software [31] to generate theoretical χ(k), which were compared to their experimental counterparts. For the structural fitting, scattering paths up to 3.5Å were considered. Structural fitting parameters used in the model included: global lattice expansion coefficients, for Fe-C and Fe-Fe in the carbides, and Fe-O and Fe-Fe in Fe3O4 phase; two global Δe 0 (one for iron carbide and one for Fe3O4)—the overall energy shift applied to each path; Debye-Waller factors for Fe-C and Fe-Fe in iron carbide and Fe-O and Fe-Fe in Fe3O4; and amplitude coefficients that account for the fraction of each phase (Hägg carbide and Fe3O4) and changes in the amplitude due to particle size (i.e., surface atoms have lower degrees of coordination). In order to constrain the fits to achieve more physically meaningful results, the data sets were fitted simultaneously. 3 Results and discussion The effect of activation gas on CO conversion for the copper and potassium promoted iron-based catalyst (100Fe:5.1Si:1.25K:5.0Cu) is shown in Fig. 2 . CO activated catalyst exhibited higher activity than the syngas activated catalyst. In our recent study [20], the effect of activation gas (CO and syngas) was investigated by varying the copper loading of a potassium promoted iron based catalyst. The CO activated catalysts exhibited very similar conversions at steady state conversion level for various copper loaded catalysts with the only advantage being that the induction period decreased with increasing copper loading. On the other hand, for the syngas activated catalysts, with increasing copper loading, the activity passes through a maximum at about 2% copper. The effect of copper loading on the FTS product selectivities of CO- and syngas activated iron-based catalysts is compared at similar CO conversion level in Table 4 . The selectivities for the CO-activated catalysts were very similar for the various copper loaded catalysts, whereas for the syngas activated catalysts, light hydrocarbon (methane and C2-C4) selectivities decreased and higher hydrocarbon (C5+) selectivities increased with increasing copper loading. At that time, it was speculated that with syngas activation, a higher concentration of the Cu may act like K and exist in an oxidized state (e.g., +1) and provide an electronic effect that facilitates CO bond scission. For CO activated catalysts: CuO→Cu0 andFe2O3 →Fe3O4 →Fe x C For syngas (H2/CO=0.7) activated catalysts: CuO→Cu+1 +Cu0 andFe2O3 →Fe3O4 →Fe x C In our prior work [20], XRD measurements of the used catalysts were performed to shed light on the phases of Cu present and the degree of crystallinity; however, XRD peaks were not observed for Cu. The absence of copper peaks in XRD is likely due to the presence of Cu with insufficient long range order (i.e., small crystallites or a dispersed phase). To clarify that potassium exists in the +1 state after carburization, CO activated potassium promoted iron catalysts (100Fe:2.0K and 100Fe:5.0K) were investigated using XANES spectroscopy. Potassium K-edge normalized XANES results are shown in Fig. 3 , which demonstrates that K in the potassium promoted iron catalysts is indeed in the +1 oxidation state (by comparison with the literature [32]). Potassium facilitates the carburization of the catalyst and helps maintain active iron carbide during FTS [33,34]; furthermore, with increasing K loading, C5+ selectivity increases (Table 5 ). To provide further confirmation regarding the role of promoter oxidation state on the chemical promoting effect of Cu, the catalysts were subjected to the CO or syngas activation treatments and the catalyst slurry samples were withdrawn from the CSTR reactor in an inert atmosphere; one after the activation and another one following exposure to FTS reaction conditions (5 days). These catalysts were investigated using EXAFS and XANES spectroscopies. Normalized XANES spectra near the Cu K-edge for the CO and syngas activated catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . Examining first the lower series of plots, the dark solid line is for the CO-activated catalyst, while the dashed line is for the syngas-activated catalyst, immediately following the pretreatment procedure. In comparison with the white line intensities of the Cu foil and Cu2O reference compounds, the CO-activated catalyst was significantly more reduced. It was not possible to estimate the fractions of each contribution (i.e., Cu1+ and Cu0) by linear combination fitting, because of the large pre-edge feature for the Cu2O reference. However, the qualitative differences are evident. After running FTS for 5 days, there are still differences, but not as pronounced, with the syngas-activated catalyst displaying some reduction. The EXAFS signal was good only over a limited k-range of 2.5–7.5Å−1; nevertheless, a useful comparison could be extracted even over this relatively short range. The k 1-weighted Fourier Transform magnitude data are plotted in Fig. 5 for (a) the freshly activated catalysts and (b) the catalysts after exposure to FTS. At the top of the figure, references for Cu2O powder and Cu metal foil are provided for the purpose of comparison. Qualitatively, it is evident that the CO-activated catalyst shows a higher peak intensity for Cu-Cu metal coordination in comparison with the syngas-activated catalyst. This is true both immediately following activation and after exposure to FTS conditions for 5 days. The results are in good agreement with those of XANES. The syngas-activated catalyst exhibits relatively greater Cu1+ character (with higher Cu-O coordination), while the CO-activated catalyst is more reduced (with greater Cu-Cu coordination). Results of the EXAFS fittings are displayed in Fig. 6 and Table 6 . The r-factor shows that a relatively good fitting of the theoretical model to the experimental data was obtained. Turning our attention to the Fe K-edge results, normalized XANES spectra acquired near the Fe K-edge are displayed in Fig. 7 . Examining first the lower series of plots, the dark solid line is for the CO-activated catalyst, while the dashed line is for the syngas-activated catalyst, immediately following the pretreatment procedure. In comparison with the white line intensities of the Fe carbide and Fe3O4 reference compounds, the CO-activated catalyst was significantly more carburized relative to the syngas-activated catalyst. CO conversions follow similar trends with the percentage of carburization. After running FTS for 5 days, there are still differences, but not as pronounced, with the CO-activated catalyst displaying a slight increase in the white line intensity. Low temperature (20K) Mössbauer results of the same catalyst from a previous study show that after 24h of CO activation 69% of Fe was of χ-Fe5C2 and 31% of Fe was of Fe3O4, whereas after 24h syngas activation 36% of Fe was χ-Fe5C2 and 64% of Fe was Fe3O4. Carburization of iron catalysts from present XANES results provide further confirmation of the previous Mössbauer and CO-TPR measurements. The reference for Fe carbide came from a previous study, where an iron catalyst with composition 100Fe:4.6Si:1.5K was carburized for 10h at 290°C in CO, from [33], while the reference compound for Fe3O4 came from a TPR-EXAFS/XANES test for an 100Fe:4.6Si:1.5K catalyst, where the spectrum was taken from the point of maximum Fe3O4 content at 190.5°C during carburization in CO, from [33]. The k 1-weighted Fourier Transform magnitude data are plotted in Fig. 8 for (a) the freshly activated catalysts and (b) the catalysts after exposure to FTS. At the top of the figure, references for Fe carbide and Fe3O4 (both obtained from [33]) are provided for the purpose of comparison. Qualitatively, the CO-activated catalyst exhibits a higher peak intensity for Fe-Fe metal coordination in Fe carbide relative to the syngas-activated catalyst. This is true both immediately following activation and after exposure to FTS conditions for 5 days. In good agreement with the picture from XANES, the CO-activated catalyst is significantly more carburized than the syngas-activated one. Results of the EXAFS fittings are displayed in Fig. 9 and Table 7 . The r-factor of 0.017 indicates that a relatively good fit of the theoretical model to the experimental data was obtained. The amplitude parameter A for Hägg carbide is significantly higher for the CO-activated catalyst, while that of Fe3O4 is measurably higher for the syngas-activated one. The difference is maintained even after running FTS for 5 days. 4 Conclusions The Cu promoter oxidation state in Fe catalysts following either CO or syngas activation, and after exposure to FTS reaction, was investigated using EXAFS/XANES spectroscopies. Fe K-edge normalized XANES results reveal that the CO-activated catalyst was significantly more carburized relative to the syngas-activated catalyst; therefore, as Fe carbides are essential to FTS activity, the CO activated catalyst exhibited higher activity than the syngas activated catalyst. Cu K-edge normalized XANES results indicate that the syngas-activated catalyst exhibited relatively higher Cu1+ character (with greater Cu-O coordination in EXAFS), while the CO-activated catalyst was more reduced (with greater Cu-Cu metal coordination in EXAFS). The fraction of Cu1+ was higher in the syngas activated catalyst. This fraction of Cu1+ behaved like K1+ electronic promoter; hence, the average molecular weight of the FTS products increased with increasing copper loading (i.e., and therefore, increasing Cu1+ content). coredata.dc:description: The effect of activation gas on the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) performance of copper and potassium promoted precipitated iron-based catalysts was investigated in an earlier study [Catal. Lett. 144 (2014) 1624-1635]. In that study, CO and syngas (H2/CO=0.7) activation methods were tested after varying the copper promoter loading (0, 2, and 5%, atomic ratios relative to iron). At similar CO conversion level, the selectivities for the CO-activated catalysts were identical for the various copper loaded catalysts, whereas for the syngas activated catalysts, light hydrocarbon (methane and C2–C4) selectivities decreased and higher hydrocarbon (C5+) selectivities increased with increasing copper loading. To understand the reason for that behavior, the catalyst samples were characterized by XANES/EXAFS spectroscopy following each activation procedure before and after exposure to FTS conditions. Cu K-edge normalized XANES results indicate that for the syngas activated catalyst copper is present primarily in the Cu1+ state, whereas for CO activated catalyst the copper is more reduced (greater fraction in the Cu0 state). The Cu1+ in the syngas activated catalyst behaved like K1+; therefore, the C5+ selectivity was enhanced and light hydrocarbon selectivity was suppressed.
coredata.dc:title: Selectivity control of Cu promoted iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst by tuning the oxidation state of Cu to mimic K
